newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer sees Lovenox/Clexane sales up.
newsitem.headline: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer sees Lovenox/Clexane sales up.

text.p: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc expects sales of its leading drug Lovenox/Clexane to rise in 1997 to US$475-$500 million compared with $400 million in 1996, David Manwaring, general manager and director for Singapore, said on Tuesday.
Michel Lienard, vice president of RPR Asia-Pacific, said the drug was the company's number one product and was in one of the fastest growing markets in the world.
Lovenox/Clexane is used to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following hip and knee surgery.
When asked what expectations the company had for global sales of the drug in 1997, Manwaring said they would rise to between $475 and $500 million from last year's $400 million.
The officials were speaking at the ground breaking ceremony in Singapore of a bulk chemical factory.
Building work on the Singapore $75 million (US$51 million) plant will begin in September. The plant is expected to produce enoxaparin sodium -- the active ingredient in Lovenox/Clexane -- from 1999.
Lienard said the market for DVT was one of the fastest growing in the world and was expected to grow to $7.6 billion by 2000, compared with $4.2 billion in 1996.
RPR is 68.3 percent owned by France's Rhone-Poulenc SA, which reported a 14 percent increase in first half profits last week.
The contribution from RPR fell 9.7 percent to 1.861 billion francs (US$300 million).
